content: Here is my first actual mathematical contribution to mathlib, proving the relation k * (k - l - 1) = (n - k - 1) * m holding for strongly regular graphs. I'd like to get a review of it
Note that the implemented proof assumes there is a vertex, and furthermore the relation does not hold if n = 0, hence the extra hypothesis 0 < n
(I can say the null graph is strongly regular with parameters (0, 70, 1, 10) and these params don't satisfy the relation obviously)
(Indeed McKay writes that a graph with 0 vertices is persona non grata)
